title: Art, Liturgy, and Sacred Space in Gothic Europe
description: This advanced seminar explores the architecture and allied arts that created sacred environments for liturgical rites in high medieval Europe (twelfth–fourteenth century). Reading-centered class meetings form the basis for understanding Gothic cathedrals as multimedia spaces; discussions range from theoretical considerations of sacred sites and performance to fine-grained analyses of particular buildings’ histories and material furnishings. The course culminates in a trip to Europe (12–14 days, in the latter half of May) to visit Notre-Dame Cathedral and Sainte-Chapelle in Paris; Chartres Cathedral; Reims Cathedral; Strasbourg Cathedral; the churches of St. Maria im Kapitol and St. Ursula in Cologne; Bamberg Cathedral; and Naumburg Cathedral. Throughout the term, each student researches a specific building, using the written and photographic sources available in libraries. These form the basis of on-site presentations of the buildings to the class and final papers. During our visits to the churches, students photograph and make notes on their experiences; and they add these observations to the research papers they have already undertaken, reflecting on how their personal encounters with the space enhanced, conformed to, undermined, or opened up new aspects of their expectations gleaned from the secondary sources. The class thus operates on two levels: first, imparting to students a sense of the richness and intelligence of Gothic sacred environments, and second, helping them find a way of balancing empirical scholarly research with their own subjective and dynamic encounters as they write about historical buildings.
